title: Η Le Soir μιλάει για ενδεχόμενο "Russia Gate" στην Ευρωπαϊκή Ένωση
cleaned_sentences: Le Soir is talking about 'Russia Gate' in the European Union Source of Photography: Internet // As the Belgian newspaper points out, European Secret Services have identified a network aimed at misinformation and influence in view of the June European elections through the pro -Russian website "Voice of Europe".
"A" Russiagate "is struck above the European Parliament two months before the election" is the title of article in the Belgian newspaper "Le Soir".

As noted, European Secret Services (Czech Republic, Belgium, Germany, France, the Netherlands, Hungary, Poland) identified a network aimed at misinformation and influence in view of the June European elections through the pro -Russian website "Voice of Europe".
It is noted that some MEPs, mainly by the ID group, were allegedly paid by a pro -Russian organization.
The Czechs also announced that their research showed that Ukrainian oligarch Victor Medvensuk, especially close to Vladimir Putin, was the funder of the Voice of Europe.
Arrested in Ukraine, Victor Medvendzuk exchanged, along with 44 other Russian prisoners of war, with 200 Ukrainian fighters in September 2022.
His partner, Artem Marsevski, a resident of Czech.
The two men were introduced on the list of people who were imposed by the Czech Republic.
"Moscow money was used to pay some political representatives spreading Russian propaganda," the Czech intelligence services added according to Soir.
Responding to the issue in the Belgian parliament, the country's Prime Minister Alexander de Croo said that "Russia has approached MEPs, but also paid them to promote Russian propaganda.
These are not innocent on social media, but MPs receiving money.
There is external pressure and internal cooperation, also in our country, at the highest levels of our democratic institutions, ”he said.
Alexander de Croo spoke of a "regional elected official" and according to the report, everyone shows Philip Degider of the far -right party Vlaams Belang.
It is emphasized in the article that "at this stage, there is no indication that a Belgian elected official has been paid by this organization" nor is there any ongoing judicial investigation.
A spokesman for the EC president noted that Roberta Metsola "is aware of the allegations that have been made and examined in particular".
The Social Democrats, for their part, asked them to have an "emergency debate", and according to the Belga agency.
Liberals and the Greens called for a survey of possible intervention in the European Parliament funded by Russia.
Finally, Renew's head Valerie Haye asked Mrs Metsola to launch an investigation Read all the latest news from Greece and the world
